title: Enhancing Generalization of Spiking Neural Networks Through Temporal Regularization
summary:
Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) have received widespread attention due to
their event-driven and low-power characteristics, making them particularly
effective for processing event-based neuromorphic data. Recent studies have
shown that directly trained SNNs suffer from severe overfitting issues due to
the limited scale of neuromorphic datasets and the gradient mismatching
problem, which fundamentally constrain their generalization performance. In
this paper, we propose a temporal regularization training (TRT) method by
introducing a time-dependent regularization mechanism to enforce stronger
constraints on early timesteps. We compare the performance of TRT with other
state-of-the-art methods performance on datasets including CIFAR10/100,
ImageNet100, DVS-CIFAR10, and N-Caltech101. To validate the effectiveness of
TRT, we conducted ablation studies and analyses including loss landscape
visualization and learning curve analysis, demonstrating that TRT can
effectively mitigate overfitting and flatten the training loss landscape,
thereby enhancing generalizability. Furthermore, we establish a theoretical
interpretation of TRT's temporal regularization mechanism based on the results
of Fisher information analysis. We analyze the temporal information dynamics
inside SNNs by tracking Fisher information during the TRT training process,
revealing the Temporal Information Concentration (TIC) phenomenon, where Fisher
information progressively concentrates in early timesteps. The time-decaying
regularization mechanism implemented in TRT effectively guides the network to
learn robust features in early timesteps with rich information, thereby leading
to significant improvements in model generalization. Code is available at
https://github.com/ZBX05/Temporal-Regularization-Training.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces Temporal Regularization Training (TRT) for Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) to address overfitting and gradient mismatching issues, improving generalization performance.
AI.motivation: Directly trained SNNs face overfitting due to small neuromorphic datasets and gradient mismatching issues, limiting their generalization ability.
AI.method: The paper proposes TRT, a training method that applies time-dependent regularization, emphasizing stronger constraints on early timesteps. The method includes Fisher information analysis to explain its mechanism.
AI.result: TRT mitigates overfitting, flattens the loss landscape, and demonstrates enhanced generalizability on multiple datasets like CIFAR10/100 and DVS-CIFAR10.
AI.conclusion: Temporal Regularization Training concentrates Fisher information on early timesteps, enabling SNNs to learn robust features and significantly improve generalization performance.

title: A Unified Platform to Evaluate STDP Learning Rule and Synapse Model using Pattern Recognition in a Spiking Neural Network
comment:
This is a preprint with 12 pages and 12 figures. It has been accepted
  for presentation at ICANN 2025. The final authenticated version will be
  available in the proceedings published by Springer in the Lecture Notes in
  Computer Science (LNCS) series
summary:
We develop a unified platform to evaluate Ideal, Linear, and Non-linear
$\text{Pr}_{0.7}\text{Ca}_{0.3}\text{MnO}_{3}$ memristor-based synapse models,
each getting progressively closer to hardware realism, alongside four STDP
learning rules in a two-layer SNN with LIF neurons and adaptive thresholds for
five-class MNIST classification. On MNIST with small train set and large test
set, our two-layer SNN with ideal, 25-state, and 12-state nonlinear memristor
synapses achieves 92.73 %, 91.07 %, and 80 % accuracy, respectively, while
converging faster and using fewer parameters than comparable ANN/CNN baselines.

AI.tldr: This paper evaluates three types of memristor-based synapse models for MNIST classification, achieving competitive accuracy with fewer resources compared to ANN/CNN baselines.
AI.motivation: To explore the efficiency and effectiveness of different memristor-based synapse models integrated with STDP learning rules in spiking neural networks (SNNs).
AI.method: The study developed a unified evaluation platform for synapse models and assessed their performance in a two-layer SNN with LIF neurons on MNIST classification. Both small train sets and large test sets were used.
AI.result: The SNN with ideal, 25-state, and 12-state nonlinear memristor synapses achieved accuracies of 92.73%, 91.07%, and 80%, respectively, and outperformed ANN/CNN baselines in convergence speed and parameter economy.
AI.conclusion: Memristor-based SNNs can achieve competitive accuracy while being more resource-efficient, highlighting their potential for hardware-efficient neural computing.

title: Signal Use and Emergent Cooperation
summary:
In this work, we investigate how autonomous agents, organized into tribes,
learn to use communication signals to coordinate their activities and enhance
their collective efficiency. Using the NEC-DAC (Neurally Encoded Culture -
Distributed Autonomous Communicators) system, where each agent is equipped with
its own neural network for decision-making, we demonstrate how these agents
develop a shared behavioral system -- akin to a culture -- through learning and
signalling. Our research focuses on the self-organization of culture within
these tribes of agents and how varying communication strategies impact their
fitness and cooperation. By analyzing different social structures, such as
authority hierarchies, we show that the culture of cooperation significantly
influences the tribe's performance. Furthermore, we explore how signals not
only facilitate the emergence of culture but also enable its transmission
across generations of agents. Additionally, we examine the benefits of
coordinating behavior and signaling within individual agents' neural networks.

AI.tldr: The paper explores how autonomous agents use communication to develop culture, improve efficiency, and transmit behaviors across generations using the NEC-DAC system.
AI.motivation: To understand how communication strategies enable self-organized cultural development and impact team efficiency in autonomous agents.
AI.method: The NEC-DAC system, equipping agents with neural networks, is used to study the development of shared behavior and the influence of communication strategies across various social structures.
AI.result: Agents demonstrate culture formation and improved cooperation, with communication playing a significant role in their coordination and cultural transmission.
AI.conclusion: The emergence and transmission of culture in autonomous systems through communication enhances tribal performance and cooperation.

title: Plan for Speed -- Dilated Scheduling for Masked Diffusion Language Models
summary:
Masked diffusion language models (MDLM) have shown strong promise for
non-autoregressive text generation, yet existing samplers act as implicit
planners, selecting tokens to unmask via denoiser confidence or entropy scores.
Such heuristics falter under parallel unmasking - they ignore pairwise
interactions between tokens and cannot account for dependencies when unmasking
multiple positions at once, limiting their inference time to traditional
auto-regressive (AR) models. We introduce the Dilated-scheduled Unmasking
Strategy (DUS), an inference-only, planner-model-free method that requires no
additional training. DUS leverages a first-order Markov assumption to partition
sequence positions into dilation-based groups of non-adjacent tokens, enabling
independent, parallel unmasking steps that respect local context that minimizes
the joint entropy of each iteration step. Unlike semi-AR block approaches
(e.g., LLADA and Dream) that still invoke the denoiser per block, DUS reduces
the number of denoiser calls to O(log B) per generation block - yielding
substantial speedup over the O(B) run time of state-of-the-art diffusion
models, where B is the block size in the semi-AR inference process. In
experiments on math (GSM8K) and code completion (Humaneval, MBPP) benchmarks -
domains suited to non-ordinal generation - DUS improves scores over parallel
confidence-based planner, without modifying the underlying denoiser. DUS offers
a lightweight, budget-aware approach to efficient, high-quality text
generation, paving the way to unlock the true capabilities of MDLMs.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces Dilated-scheduled Unmasking Strategy (DUS), an efficient inference method for Masked Diffusion Language Models (MDLMs) that dramatically reduces denoiser calls while improving text generation quality.
AI.motivation: Existing masked diffusion language models rely on heuristics like denoiser confidence or entropy scores for unmasking tokens, which fail to handle dependencies when unmasking multiple positions in parallel. This limits their performance compared to auto-regressive models.
AI.method: The authors propose DUS, a planner-free approach based on a first-order Markov assumption. It organizes sequence positions using dilation groups of non-adjacent tokens, unmasking them independently and in parallel, while minimizing joint entropy at each step. Unlike existing semi-autoregressive methods, DUS uses O(log B) denoiser calls per generation block.
AI.result: Experiments on math (GSM8K) and code completion (Humaneval, MBPP) benchmarks show that DUS improves performance over confidence-based planners without altering the denoiser, achieving significant computational efficiency.
AI.conclusion: DUS establishes an efficient, lightweight, and high-quality text generation method for MDLMs without additional training, enabling better exploitation of their potential and outperforming state-of-the-art alternatives in both speed and quality.

title: MEDEA: A Design-Time Multi-Objective Manager for Energy-Efficient DNN Inference on Heterogeneous Ultra-Low Power Platforms
comment: Submitted to ACM Transactions on Embedded Computing Systems (TECS)
summary:
The growing demand for on-device AI necessitates energy-efficient execution
of DNN based applications on resource-constrained ultra-low power (ULP)
platforms. Heterogeneous architectures, combining specialized processing
elements (PEs), have emerged as a key solution for achieving the required
performance and energy efficiency. However, optimizing energy while executing
applications on these platforms requires efficiently managing platform
resources like PEs, power features, and memory footprint, all while adhering to
critical application deadlines. This paper presents MEDEA, a novel design-time
multi-objective manager for energy-efficient DNN inference on Heterogeneous ULP
(HULP) platforms. MEDEA uniquely integrates: kernel-level dynamic voltage and
frequency scaling (DVFS) for dynamic energy adaptation; kernel-level
granularity scheduling, suitable for specialized accelerators; memory-aware
adaptive tiling to navigate severe memory constraints; and all within a timing
constraint-based optimization strategy, which minimizes energy based on
application deadline. To showcase practical viability, we evaluate MEDEA on
HEEPtimize, a heterogeneous ULP platform (22 nm, FPGA-prototyped) featuring a
RISC-V processor besides Near-Memory Computing (NMC) and Coarse-Grained
Reconfigurable Array (CGRA) accelerators. Experimental results, using a
biomedical seizure detection case study, demonstrate that MEDEA achieves
overall energy reductions of up to 38% compared to representative
state-of-the-art methods, while consistently meeting all timing and memory
requirements. This effectiveness is attributed to its integrated features, with
our analysis showing that kernel-level DVFS alone can be responsible for over
31% of the energy savings in specific scenarios.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces MEDEA, a design-time manager for energy-efficient DNN inference on heterogeneous ultra-low power platforms, achieving up to 38% energy reductions by integrating techniques like kernel-level DVFS and memory-aware adaptive tiling.
AI.motivation: The need for efficient execution of deep neural networks (DNNs) on resource-constrained ultra-low power platforms motivates the development of a solution that balances energy efficiency with performance and application deadlines.
AI.method: MEDEA combines kernel-level DVFS, kernel granularity scheduling, memory-aware adaptive tiling, and timing constraint-based optimization strategies to manage platform resources efficiently.
AI.result: The MEDEA framework demonstrated a 38% reduction in energy consumption compared to state-of-the-art methods while adhering to timing and memory requirements in experiments using HEEPtimize.
AI.conclusion: MEDEA's integrated approach is highly effective for energy-efficient DNN inference on heterogeneous ULP platforms, with significant contributions from kernel-level DVFS and other optimization techniques.

title: PEVLM: Parallel Encoding for Vision-Language Models
summary:
Vision-Language Models (VLMs) have demonstrated strong performance in
video-language tasks, yet their application to long video understanding remains
constrained by the quadratic complexity of standard attention mechanisms. In
this paper, we propose \textbf{PEVLM}, a parallel encoding strategy
specifically designed to improve the prefill efficiency of VLMs without
requiring model finetuning. PEVLM partitions the input into block-wise segments
with a shared sink, preserves full-attention positional embeddings, and aligns
attention weights to mimic full-attention distributions. This design reduces
attention computation from $O((T \times N)^2)$ to $O(T \times N)$ while
maintaining high accuracy. Extensive experiments on the LongVideoBench
benchmark show that PEVLM achieves up to 8.37\% accuracy improvement over
existing inference-efficient methods and delivers up to 7.47x speedup in
attention computation and 40\% reduction in end-to-end latency. Under strict
latency constraints, PEVLM significantly outperforms baselines, raising
accuracy from 23.26\% to 61.03\%. These results highlight PEVLM's effectiveness
for low-latency, long-context video understanding, making it well-suited for
real-world applications such as autonomous driving.

AI.tldr: PEVLM introduces a parallel encoding strategy to improve the efficiency of Vision-Language Models (VLMs) for long video understanding with reduced computation and latency, achieving superior accuracy and speed compared to existing methods.
AI.motivation: Existing Vision-Language Models struggle with long video understanding due to the high computational cost of standard attention mechanisms.
AI.method: PEVLM employs a parallel encoding strategy by partitioning input into block-wise segments with a shared sink, preserving full-attention positional embeddings, and aligning attention weights to imitate full-attention distributions.
AI.result: PEVLM offers up to 8.37% accuracy improvement, 7.47x computation speedup, and 40% latency reduction on LongVideoBench compared to current efficient inference methods.
AI.conclusion: PEVLM effectively addresses low-latency and long-context video understanding challenges, proving beneficial for applications including autonomous driving.

title: Survey of HPC in US Research Institutions
summary:
The rapid growth of AI, data-intensive science, and digital twin technologies
has driven an unprecedented demand for high-performance computing (HPC) across
the research ecosystem. While national laboratories and industrial hyperscalers
have invested heavily in exascale and GPU-centric architectures,
university-operated HPC systems remain comparatively under-resourced. This
survey presents a comprehensive assessment of the HPC landscape across U.S.
universities, benchmarking their capabilities against Department of Energy
(DOE) leadership-class systems and industrial AI infrastructures. We examine
over 50 premier research institutions, analyzing compute capacity,
architectural design, governance models, and energy efficiency. Our findings
reveal that university clusters, though vital for academic research, exhibit
significantly lower growth trajectories (CAGR $\approx$ 18%) than their
national ($\approx$ 43%) and industrial ($\approx$ 78%) counterparts. The
increasing skew toward GPU-dense AI workloads has widened the capability gap,
highlighting the need for federated computing, idle-GPU harvesting, and
cost-sharing models. We also identify emerging paradigms, such as decentralized
reinforcement learning, as promising opportunities for democratizing AI
training within campus environments. Ultimately, this work provides actionable
insights for academic leaders, funding agencies, and technology partners to
ensure more equitable and sustainable HPC access in support of national
research priorities.

AI.tldr: This paper surveys HPC usage in U.S. universities, highlights the performance gap compared to national and industrial infrastructures, and suggests strategies to improve access.
AI.motivation: The demand for HPC is growing due to advancements in AI, data-intensive science, and digital twin technologies. Universities lack the resources to keep pace with national and industrial HPC systems, creating disparities.
AI.method: The paper benchmarks HPC capabilities at over 50 U.S. research universities against DOE systems and industrial AI platforms. It examines factors like compute capacity, architecture, governance, and energy efficiency.
AI.result: University HPC systems have lower growth rates (~18% CAGR) than national (~43%) and industrial (~78%) systems, with a widening GPU-centric capability gap. Emerging methods like federated computing and decentralized learning are suggested.
AI.conclusion: Academic leaders and stakeholders are advised to adopt federated models, GPU utilization strategies, and new AI paradigms to democratize access, ensuring HPC sustainability and equity for research advancement.

title: Mix-of-Language-Experts Architecture for Multilingual Programming
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated impressive capabilities in
aiding developers with tasks like code comprehension, generation, and
translation. Supporting multilingual programming -- i.e., coding tasks across
multiple programming languages -- typically requires either (1) finetuning a
single LLM across all programming languages, which is cost-efficient but
sacrifices language-specific specialization and performance, or (2) finetuning
separate LLMs for each programming language, which allows for specialization
but is computationally expensive and storage-intensive due to the duplication
of parameters. This paper introduces MoLE (Mix-of-Language-Experts), a novel
architecture that balances efficiency and specialization for multilingual
programming. MoLE is composed of a base model, a shared LoRA (low-rank
adaptation) module, and a collection of language-specific LoRA modules. These
modules are jointly optimized during the finetuning process, enabling effective
knowledge sharing and specialization across programming languages. During
inference, MoLE automatically routes to the language-specific LoRA module
corresponding to the programming language of the code token being generated.
Our experiments demonstrate that MoLE achieves greater parameter efficiency
compared to training separate language-specific LoRAs, while outperforming a
single shared LLM finetuned for all programming languages in terms of accuracy.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes MoLE, a new architecture for multilingual programming support, combining efficiency and specialization through shared and language-specific LoRA modules.
AI.motivation: Existing methods for multilingual programming either sacrifice performance by using a single LLM across all languages or incur high costs by finetuning separate LLMs for each language.
AI.method: MoLE utilizes a base model with both shared and language-specific LoRA modules, optimized jointly during finetuning for knowledge sharing and specialization. Language-specific inference is handled automatically.
AI.result: MoLE achieves better parameter efficiency compared to separate language-specific LoRAs and outperforms a single shared LLM trained on all programming languages.
AI.conclusion: MoLE effectively balances efficiency and performance for multilingual programming tasks, making it a promising solution for code generation and comprehension across various languages.

title: MemeMind: A Large-Scale Multimodal Dataset with Chain-of-Thought Reasoning for Harmful Meme Detection
summary:
The rapid development of social media has intensified the spread of harmful
content. Harmful memes, which integrate both images and text, pose significant
challenges for automated detection due to their implicit semantics and complex
multimodal interactions. Although existing research has made progress in
detection accuracy and interpretability, the lack of a systematic, large-scale,
diverse, and highly explainable dataset continues to hinder further advancement
in this field. To address this gap, we introduce MemeMind, a novel dataset
featuring scientifically rigorous standards, large scale, diversity, bilingual
support (Chinese and English), and detailed Chain-of-Thought (CoT) annotations.
MemeMind fills critical gaps in current datasets by offering comprehensive
labeling and explicit reasoning traces, thereby providing a solid foundation
for enhancing harmful meme detection. In addition, we propose an innovative
detection framework, MemeGuard, which effectively integrates multimodal
information with reasoning process modeling, significantly improving models'
ability to understand and identify harmful memes. Extensive experiments
conducted on the MemeMind dataset demonstrate that MemeGuard consistently
outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods in harmful meme detection tasks.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a novel dataset, MemeMind, and a framework, MemeGuard, to address challenges in harmful meme detection, achieving superior results.
AI.motivation: To overcome limitations in current datasets and methods for detecting harmful memes, focusing on semantic and multimodal complexities.
AI.method: Developed MemeMind, a bilingual and annotated dataset, and created MemeGuard, a framework integrating multimodal information and reasoning processes.
AI.result: MemeGuard outperformed existing methods in harmful meme detection tasks based on experiments using the MemeMind dataset.
AI.conclusion: MemeMind and MemeGuard set a new benchmark in this field, particularly through enhanced understanding and detection of harmful memes.

title: Correspondence-Free Multiview Point Cloud Registration via Depth-Guided Joint Optimisation
comment:
8 pages, accepted for publication in IEEE/RSJ International
  Conference on Intelligent Robots and Systems (IROS 2025)
summary:
Multiview point cloud registration is a fundamental task for constructing
globally consistent 3D models. Existing approaches typically rely on feature
extraction and data association across multiple point clouds; however, these
processes are challenging to obtain global optimal solution in complex
environments. In this paper, we introduce a novel correspondence-free multiview
point cloud registration method. Specifically, we represent the global map as a
depth map and leverage raw depth information to formulate a non-linear least
squares optimisation that jointly estimates poses of point clouds and the
global map. Unlike traditional feature-based bundle adjustment methods, which
rely on explicit feature extraction and data association, our method bypasses
these challenges by associating multi-frame point clouds with a global depth
map through their corresponding poses. This data association is implicitly
incorporated and dynamically refined during the optimisation process. Extensive
evaluations on real-world datasets demonstrate that our method outperforms
state-of-the-art approaches in accuracy, particularly in challenging
environments where feature extraction and data association are difficult.

AI.tldr: The paper presents a new correspondence-free approach to multiview point cloud registration, bypassing traditional feature extraction and achieving better accuracy through optimization with global depth maps.
AI.motivation: Existing methods face challenges in obtaining globally optimal solutions in complex environments due to reliance on feature extraction and data association.
AI.method: The method formulates a non-linear least squares optimization to jointly estimate point cloud poses and a global depth map, without explicit feature-based processes.
AI.result: Evaluations on real-world datasets show superior accuracy against state-of-the-art methods, especially in challenging environments.
AI.conclusion: The proposed approach effectively addresses limitations of feature-based methods by dynamically incorporating and refining data association through the optimization process, enabling robust multiview point cloud registration.

title: HI-SQL: Optimizing Text-to-SQL Systems through Dynamic Hint Integration
summary:
Text-to-SQL generation bridges the gap between natural language and
databases, enabling users to query data without requiring SQL expertise. While
large language models (LLMs) have significantly advanced the field, challenges
remain in handling complex queries that involve multi-table joins, nested
conditions, and intricate operations. Existing methods often rely on multi-step
pipelines that incur high computational costs, increase latency, and are prone
to error propagation. To address these limitations, we propose HI-SQL, a
pipeline that incorporates a novel hint generation mechanism utilizing
historical query logs to guide SQL generation. By analyzing prior queries, our
method generates contextual hints that focus on handling the complexities of
multi-table and nested operations. These hints are seamlessly integrated into
the SQL generation process, eliminating the need for costly multi-step
approaches and reducing reliance on human-crafted prompts. Experimental
evaluations on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach
significantly improves query accuracy of LLM-generated queries while ensuring
efficiency in terms of LLM calls and latency, offering a robust and practical
solution for enhancing Text-to-SQL systems.

AI.tldr: Proposes HI-SQL, a method utilizing historical query logs for efficient and accurate Text-to-SQL generation.
AI.motivation: To enable efficient and accurate Text-to-SQL queries for complex database operations using large language models, addressing current issues like high costs, latency, and error propagation.
AI.method: Introduces a hint generation mechanism leveraging historical query logs to create contextual hints for SQL generation, seamlessly integrating them into the generation process.
AI.result: Demonstrated improved query accuracy, reduced computational costs, and better efficiency in experimental benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: HI-SQL offers a robust and practical solution to enhance Text-to-SQL systems, particularly for complex queries.

title: FORTE: Tactile Force and Slip Sensing on Compliant Fingers for Delicate Manipulation
summary:
Handling delicate and fragile objects remains a major challenge for robotic
manipulation, especially for rigid parallel grippers. While the simplicity and
versatility of parallel grippers have led to widespread adoption, these
grippers are limited by their heavy reliance on visual feedback. Tactile
sensing and soft robotics can add responsiveness and compliance. However,
existing methods typically involve high integration complexity or suffer from
slow response times. In this work, we introduce FORTE, a tactile sensing system
embedded in compliant gripper fingers. FORTE uses 3D-printed fin-ray grippers
with internal air channels to provide low-latency force and slip feedback.
FORTE applies just enough force to grasp objects without damaging them, while
remaining easy to fabricate and integrate. We find that FORTE can accurately
estimate grasping forces from 0-8 N with an average error of 0.2 N, and detect
slip events within 100 ms of occurring. We demonstrate FORTE's ability to grasp
a wide range of slippery, fragile, and deformable objects. In particular, FORTE
grasps fragile objects like raspberries and potato chips with a 98.6% success
rate, and achieves 93% accuracy in detecting slip events. These results
highlight FORTE's potential as a robust and practical solution for enabling
delicate robotic manipulation. Project page: https://merge-lab.github.io/FORTE

AI.tldr: FORTE is a tactile sensing system integrated into compliant gripper fingers that achieves precise and responsive grasping of fragile objects using 3D-printed fin-ray grippers with internal air channels.
AI.motivation: Gripping delicate and fragile objects is challenging for rigid parallel robotic grippers due to their dependence on visual feedback and lack of compliance.
AI.method: The authors developed FORTE, a 3D-printed tactile gripper system with internal air channels for low-latency force and slip feedback, combining soft robotics and tactile sensing technologies.
AI.result: FORTE estimates grasping forces with 0.2 N error within a range of 0-8 N, identifies slip events within 100 ms, and successfully grasps fragile objects like raspberries and potato chips with a 98.6% success rate.
AI.conclusion: FORTE proves effective for handling delicate and deformable objects, offering an easy-to-fabricate and robust solution for improving robotic manipulation.

title: Black-Box Test Code Fault Localization Driven by Large Language Models and Execution Estimation
summary:
Fault localization (FL) is a critical step in debugging which typically
relies on repeated executions to pinpoint faulty code regions. However,
repeated executions can be impractical in the presence of non-deterministic
failures or high execution costs. While recent efforts have leveraged Large
Language Models (LLMs) to aid execution-free FL, these have primarily focused
on identifying faults in the system under test (SUT) rather than in the often
complex system test code. However, the latter is also important as, in
practice, many failures are triggered by faulty test code. To overcome these
challenges, we introduce a fully static, LLM-driven approach for system test
code fault localization (TCFL) that does not require executing the test case.
Our method uses a single failure execution log to estimate the test's execution
trace through three novel algorithms that identify only code statements likely
involved in the failure. This pruned trace, combined with the error message, is
used to prompt the LLM to rank potential faulty locations. Our black-box,
system-level approach requires no access to the SUT source code and is
applicable to large test scripts that assess full system behavior. We evaluate
our technique at function, block, and line levels using an industrial dataset
of faulty test cases not previously used in pre-training LLMs. Results show
that our best estimated trace closely match actual traces, with an F1 score of
around 90%. Additionally, pruning the complex system test code reduces the
LLM's inference time by up to 34% without any loss in FL performance. Our
results further suggest that block-level TCFL offers a practical balance,
narrowing the search space while preserving useful context, achieving an 81%
hit rate at top-3 (Hit@3).

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a static, Large Language Model (LLM)-driven method for fault localization in complex system test code, eliminating the need for test case execution.
AI.motivation: Faulty test code can often trigger system failures, yet existing methods for fault localization focus on the system-under-test rather than test code, which is equally critical. High execution costs and non-deterministic test failures further necessitate execution-free fault localization techniques.
AI.method: The method uses a single failure execution log to estimate execution traces through three novel pruning algorithms. These traces and error messages are used to prompt an LLM to rank potential faulty locations. The approach is black-box, requires no source code access, and supports large test scripts.
AI.result: The method achieved an F1 score of around 90% in matching estimated traces with actual ones and reduced LLM inference time by up to 34% without losing fault localization accuracy. Block-level localization hit rates were 81% within the top-3 ranked suggestions.
AI.conclusion: The proposed approach is effective for execution-free fault localization in complex system test code, providing a practical and efficient solution for narrowing the search space and retaining impactful context.

title: Simulation-Based Sensitivity Analysis in Optimal Treatment Regimes and Causal Decomposition with Individualized Interventions
summary:
Causal decomposition analysis aims to assess the effect of modifying risk
factors on reducing social disparities in outcomes. Recently, this analysis has
incorporated individual characteristics when modifying risk factors by
utilizing optimal treatment regimes (OTRs). Since the newly defined
individualized effects rely on the no omitted confounding assumption,
developing sensitivity analyses to account for potential omitted confounding is
essential. Moreover, OTRs and individualized effects are primarily based on
binary risk factors, and no formal approach currently exists to benchmark the
strength of omitted confounding using observed covariates for binary risk
factors. To address this gap, we extend a simulation-based sensitivity analysis
that simulates unmeasured confounders, addressing two sources of bias emerging
from deriving OTRs and estimating individualized effects. Additionally, we
propose a formal bounding strategy that benchmarks the strength of omitted
confounding for binary risk factors. Using the High School Longitudinal Study
2009 (HSLS:09), we demonstrate this sensitivity analysis and benchmarking
method.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces methods to address confounding risk in causal decomposition analysis when assessing risk factors and social disparities by extending sensitivity analysis and proposing a bounding strategy.
AI.motivation: The study seeks to improve causal decomposition analysis, enabling robust consideration of omitted confounding and broaden its applicability with binary risk factors to assess social disparities.
AI.method: It develops an advanced simulation-based sensitivity analysis to handle unmeasured confounders and proposes a benchmarking strategy to quantify omitted confounding for binary risk factors.
AI.result: The authors demonstrate their methods using real-world data, specifically the High School Longitudinal Study 2009, addressing biases in deriving optimal treatment regimes and estimating individualized effects.
AI.conclusion: This framework enhances the precision and reliability of causal decomposition analysis by tackling omitted confounders, providing significant tools to deepen social disparities research.

title: Automatic Depression Assessment using Machine Learning: A Comprehensive Survey
summary:
Depression is a common mental illness across current human society.
Traditional depression assessment relying on inventories and interviews with
psychologists frequently suffer from subjective diagnosis results, slow and
expensive diagnosis process as well as lack of human resources. Since there is
a solid evidence that depression is reflected by various human internal brain
activities and external expressive behaviours, early traditional machine
learning (ML) and advanced deep learning (DL) models have been widely explored
for human behaviour-based automatic depression assessment (ADA) since 2012.
However, recent ADA surveys typically only focus on a limited number of human
behaviour modalities. Despite being used as a theoretical basis for developing
ADA approaches, existing ADA surveys lack a comprehensive review and summary of
multi-modal depression-related human behaviours. To bridge this gap, this paper
specifically summarises depression-related human behaviours across a range of
modalities (e.g. the human brain, verbal language and non-verbal
audio/facial/body behaviours). We focus on conducting an up-to-date and
comprehensive survey of ML-based ADA approaches for learning depression cues
from these behaviours as well as discussing and comparing their distinctive
features and limitations. In addition, we also review existing ADA competitions
and datasets, identify and discuss the main challenges and opportunities to
provide further research directions for future ADA researchers.

AI.tldr: Depression assessment currently faces challenges such as subjectivity and lack of efficiency. This paper reviews machine learning techniques for automatic depression assessment using multi-modal human behaviors, discussions on datasets, challenges, and future research directions.
AI.motivation: Traditional methods for depression diagnosis face issues like subjectivity, delays, costs, and workforce shortages. Machine learning offers potential solutions, but no comprehensive review exists exploring multi-modal behavior analysis.
AI.method: The paper surveys machine learning-based automatic depression assessment techniques that analyze depression cues from various human behaviors, comparing features, limitations, and summarizing existing datasets and competitions.
AI.result: The study provides a detailed summary of depression-related human behaviors across multiple modalities, evaluates ADA techniques, discusses limitations, and identifies research gaps.
AI.conclusion: The paper bridges critical gaps in ADA research by offering an in-depth review and proposing directions for future studies, emphasizing the need for multi-modal analysis and addressing existing challenges.

title: Local Learning Rules for Out-of-Equilibrium Physical Generative Models
summary:
We show that the out-of-equilibrium driving protocol of score-based
generative models (SGMs) can be learned via a local learning rule. The gradient
with respect to the parameters of the driving protocol are computed directly
from force measurements or from observed system dynamics. As a demonstration,
we implement an SGM in a network of driven, nonlinear, overdamped oscillators
coupled to a thermal bath. We first apply it to the problem of sampling from a
mixture of two Gaussians in 2D. Finally, we train a network of 10x10
oscillators to sample images of 0s and 1s from the MNIST dataset.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a method to train score-based generative models (SGMs) using a local learning rule derived from observed dynamics or force measurements.
AI.motivation: The authors aim to leverage SGMs in complex systems and provide an efficient method for training models by directly utilizing dynamic observations.
AI.method: The study computes gradients for the driving protocol through local learning rules based on force measurements or system dynamics, applying them in a network of nonlinear oscillators coupled to a thermal bath.
AI.result: Implemented SGMs successfully generated samples from a mixture of Gaussians and trained oscillators to produce MNIST digit images.
AI.conclusion: Score-based generative models can effectively be trained via local learning rules to achieve sampling tasks in both mathematical distributions and complex datasets like MNIST.

title: In-Memory Sorting-Searching with Cayley Tree
summary:
This work proposes a computing model to reduce the workload of CPU. It relies
on the data intensive computation in memory, where the data reside, and
effectively realizes an in-memory computing (IMC) platform. Each memory word,
with additional logic, acts as a tiny processing element which forms the node
of a Cayley tree. The Cayley tree in turn defines the framework for solving the
data intensive computational problems. It finds the solutions for in-memory
searching, computing the max (min) in-memory and in-memory sorting while
reducing the involvement of CPU. The worst case time complexities of the IMC
based solutions for in-memory searching and computing max (min) in-memory are
$\mathcal{O}\log{n}$. Such solutions are independent of the order of elements
in the list. The worst case time complexity of in-memory sorting, on the other
hand, is $\mathcal{O}(n\log{n})$. Two types of hardware implementations of the
IMC platform are proposed. One is based on the existing/conventional memory
architecture, and the other one is on a newly defined memory architecture. The
solutions are further implemented in FPGA platform to prove the effectiveness
of the IMC architecture while comparing with the state-of-the art designs.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a computing model using in-memory computing (IMC) to reduce CPU workload by employing Cayley tree-based logic and implementing it on FPGA.
AI.motivation: Reducing CPU workload in data-intensive tasks by utilizing memory as a compute platform.
AI.method: Model incorporates a Cayley tree framework for computational tasks, and hardware systems using conventional and new memory architectures are implemented.
AI.result: Worst-case complexities for searching and max/min computation within IMC are O(log n), while sorting complexity is O(n log n). Implementations show competitive performance against existing designs.
AI.conclusion: IMC platform is demonstrated as a viable alternative for data-intensive computation, offering efficiency in isolated tasks with FPGA validation.

title: Vertex addition to a ball graph with application to reliability and area coverage in autonomous swarms
summary:
A unit ball graph consists of a set of vertices, labeled by points in
Euclidean space, and edges joining all pairs of points within distance $1$.
These geometric graphs are used to model a variety of spatial networks,
including communication networks between agents in an autonomous swarm. In such
an application, vertices and/or edges of the graph may not be perfectly
reliable; an agent may experience failure or a communication link rendered
inoperable. With the goal of designing robust swarm formations, or unit ball
graphs with high reliability (probability of connectedness), in a preliminary
conference paper we provided an algorithm with cubic time complexity to
determine all possible changes to a unit ball graph by repositioning a single
vertex. Using this algorithm and Monte Carlo simulations, one obtains an
efficient method to modify a unit ball graph by moving a single vertex to a
location which maximizes the reliability. Another important consideration in
many swarm missions is area coverage, yet highly reliable ball graphs often
contain clusters of vertices. Here, we generalize our previous algorithm to
improve area coverage as well as reliability. Our algorithm determines a
location to add or move a vertex within a unit ball graph which maximizes the
reliability, under the constraint that no other vertices of the graph be within
some fixed distance. We compare this method of obtaining graphs with high
reliability and evenly distributed area coverage to another method which uses a
modified Fruchterman-Reingold algorithm for ball graphs.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a generalized algorithm to optimize unit ball graphs for both reliability and area coverage by strategically adding or moving vertices, addressing challenges such as agent failure in swarm networks.
AI.motivation: The motivation behind the research is to enhance the reliability and area coverage of unit ball graphs, which are used to model spatial networks like communication networks in autonomous swarms. This is crucial due to potential failures in agents or communication links.
AI.method: The authors generalize their earlier cubic-time complexity algorithm for optimizing unit ball graphs, allowing repositioning or addition of vertices for maximizing connectivity reliability while ensuring vertices are evenly distributed for area coverage.
AI.result: The proposed approach provides a method to improve the reliability and spatial distribution in unit ball graphs by determining optimal vertex placement. The results are compared to a method using a modified Fruchterman-Reingold algorithm.
AI.conclusion: The algorithm successfully balances reliability and area coverage in unit ball graphs, making it useful for designing robust and evenly distributed swarm networks.

title: The Autonomous Data Language -- Concepts, Design and Formal Verification
summary:
Nowadays, the main advances in computational power are due to parallelism.
However, most parallel languages have been designed with a focus on processors
and threads. This makes dealing with data and memory in programs hard, which
distances the implementation from its original algorithm. We propose a new
paradigm for parallel programming, the data-autonomous paradigm, where
computation is performed by autonomous data elements. Programs in this paradigm
are focused on making the data collaborate in a highly parallel fashion. We
furthermore present AuDaLa, the first data autonomous programming language, and
provide a full formalisation that includes a type system and operational
semantics. Programming in AuDaLa is very natural, as illustrated by examples,
albeit in a style very different from sequential and contemporary parallel
programming. Additionally, it lends itself for the formal verification of
parallel programs, which we demonstrate.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces the data-autonomous paradigm for parallel programming and presents the language AuDaLa, focusing on collaborative data elements for computation.
AI.motivation: Traditional parallel languages focus primarily on threads and processors, making data and memory management challenging and distancing implementation from its algorithmic roots.
AI.method: The authors propose a new programming paradigm centered on autonomous data elements, formalize it via AuDaLa with a type system and operational semantics, and illustrate its usage through examples.
AI.result: AuDaLa simplifies programming for data collaboration in parallel systems and allows formal verification of parallel programs.
AI.conclusion: The data-autonomous paradigm offers a natural and innovative approach for parallel programming and enhances formal verification, though it constitutes a departure from current programming styles.

title: Do LLMs Know When to Flip a Coin? Strategic Randomization through Reasoning and Experience
summary:
Strategic randomization is a key principle in game theory, yet it remains
underexplored in large language models (LLMs). Prior work often conflates the
cognitive decision to randomize with the mechanical generation of randomness,
leading to incomplete evaluations. To address this, we propose a novel zero-sum
game inspired by the Tian Ji Horse Race, where the Nash equilibrium corresponds
to a maximal entropy strategy. The game's complexity masks this property from
untrained humans and underdeveloped LLMs. We evaluate five LLMs across prompt
styles -- framed, neutral, and hinted -- using competitive multi-tournament
gameplay with system-provided random choices, isolating the decision to
randomize. Results show that weaker models remain deterministic regardless of
prompts, while stronger models exhibit increased randomization under explicit
hints. When facing weaker models, strong LLMs adopt deterministic strategies to
exploit biases, but converge toward equilibrium play when facing peers. Through
win/loss outcomes and Bayes factor analysis, we demonstrate meaningful
variation in LLMs' strategic reasoning capabilities, highlighting opportunities
for improvement in abstract reasoning and adaptive learning. We make our
implementation publicly available at
https://github.com/ocelopus/llm-when-to-throw-coin to ensure full
reproducibility.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates strategic randomization in large language models (LLMs) through a zero-sum game inspired by the Tian Ji Horse Race, evaluating their ability to use randomness strategically.
AI.motivation: The authors aim to explore and evaluate the strategic decision-making and randomization abilities of LLMs, as these aspects are underdeveloped in current models.
AI.method: The authors propose a zero-sum game with Nash equilibrium as the maximal entropy strategy and test five LLMs using different prompt styles to assess their ability to decide to randomize under competitive conditions.
AI.result: Weaker models show deterministic behavior despite prompts, while stronger models randomize more when given explicit hints but resort to deterministic strategies against weaker opponents. Strong models converge to equilibrium strategies with equal peers.
AI.conclusion: LLMs exhibit varying strategic reasoning capabilities, dependent on their strength, with weaker models needing significant improvement in abstract reasoning and randomness utilization. The implementation is shared openly for reproducibility.

title: Mirage of Mastery: Memorization Tricks LLMs into Artificially Inflated Self-Knowledge
comment: Accepted to the Pre-ACL Workshop 2025, Copenhagen
summary:
When artificial intelligence mistakes memorization for intelligence, it
creates a dangerous mirage of reasoning. Existing studies treat memorization
and self-knowledge deficits in LLMs as separate issues and do not recognize an
intertwining link that degrades the trustworthiness of LLM responses. In our
study, we utilize a novel framework to ascertain if LLMs genuinely learn
reasoning patterns from training data or merely memorize them to assume
competence across problems of similar complexity focused on STEM domains. Our
analysis shows a noteworthy problem in generalization: LLMs draw confidence
from memorized solutions to infer a higher self-knowledge about their reasoning
ability, which manifests as an over 45% inconsistency in feasibility
assessments when faced with self-validated, logically coherent task
perturbations. This effect is most pronounced in science and medicine domains,
which tend to have maximal standardized jargon and problems, further confirming
our approach. Significant wavering within the self-knowledge of LLMs also shows
flaws in current architectures and training patterns, highlighting the need for
techniques that ensure a balanced, consistent stance on models' perceptions of
their own knowledge for maximum AI explainability and trustworthiness. Our code
and results are available publicly at
https://github.com/knowledge-verse-ai/LLM-Memorization_SK_Eval-.

AI.tldr: The paper highlights issues in large language models (LLMs) mistaking memorization for reasoning ability, especially in STEM domains, leading to inconsistencies in self-knowledge assessment.
AI.motivation: To address the intertwined challenges of memorization and self-knowledge deficits in LLMs that degrade trustworthiness.
AI.method: A novel framework to evaluate whether LLMs genuinely learn reasoning or rely on memorized solutions, focusing on STEM domains with task perturbations.
AI.result: LLMs show over 45% inconsistency in self-knowledge assessment, particularly in science and medicine, pointing to fundamental flaws in current architectures and training.
AI.conclusion: Better methods are needed to ensure LLMs maintain consistent self-knowledge for trustworthy and explainable AI applications.

title: Connecting Vision and Emissions: A Behavioural AI Approach to Carbon Estimation in Road Design
summary:
We present an enhanced YOLOv8 real time vehicle detection and classification
framework, for estimating carbon emissions in urban environments. The system
enhances YOLOv8 architecture to detect, segment, and track vehicles from live
traffic video streams. Once a vehicle is localized, a dedicated deep
learning-based identification module is employed to recognize license plates
and classify vehicle types. Since YOLOv8 lacks the built-in capacity for fine
grained recognition tasks such as reading license plates or determining vehicle
attributes beyond class labels, our framework incorporates a hybrid pipeline
where each detected vehicle is tracked and its bounding box is cropped and
passed to a deep Optical Character Recognition (OCR) module. This OCR system,
composed of multiple convolutional neural network (CNN) layers, is trained
specifically for character-level detection and license plate decoding under
varied conditions such as motion blur, occlusion, and diverse font styles.
Additionally, the recognized plate information is validated using a real time
API that cross references with an external vehicle registration database to
ensure accurate classification and emission estimation. This multi-stage
approach enables precise, automated calculation of per vehicle carbon
emissions. Extensive evaluation was conducted using a diverse vehicle dataset
enriched with segmentation masks and annotated license plates. The YOLOv8
detector achieved a mean Average Precision (mAP@0.5) of approximately 71% for
bounding boxes and 70% for segmentation masks. Character level OCR accuracy
reached up to 99% with the best performing CNN model. These results affirm the
feasibility of combining real time object detection with deep OCR for practical
deployment in smart transportation systems, offering a scalable solution for
automated, vehicle specific carbon emission monitoring.

AI.tldr: This paper enhances the YOLOv8 framework for real-time vehicle detection, classification, and carbon emission estimation using a hybrid pipeline with deep OCR.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to create a scalable, automated system to estimate vehicle-specific carbon emissions in urban environments.
AI.method: The method involves enhancing YOLOv8 to detect, segment, and track vehicles, incorporating a deep OCR module for license plate recognition and classification, and cross-referencing results with a real-time database for emissions estimation.
AI.result: The YOLOv8 detector achieved 71% mAP for bounding boxes and 70% for segmentation masks. The OCR module attained 99% character-level accuracy with the best CNN model.
AI.conclusion: The approach demonstrates the feasibility of integrating real-time detection and OCR for practical deployment in smart transportation systems, offering accurate and scalable carbon monitoring.

title: From Tiny Machine Learning to Tiny Deep Learning: A Survey
summary:
The rapid growth of edge devices has driven the demand for deploying
artificial intelligence (AI) at the edge, giving rise to Tiny Machine Learning
(TinyML) and its evolving counterpart, Tiny Deep Learning (TinyDL). While
TinyML initially focused on enabling simple inference tasks on
microcontrollers, the emergence of TinyDL marks a paradigm shift toward
deploying deep learning models on severely resource-constrained hardware. This
survey presents a comprehensive overview of the transition from TinyML to
TinyDL, encompassing architectural innovations, hardware platforms, model
optimization techniques, and software toolchains. We analyze state-of-the-art
methods in quantization, pruning, and neural architecture search (NAS), and
examine hardware trends from MCUs to dedicated neural accelerators.
Furthermore, we categorize software deployment frameworks, compilers, and
AutoML tools enabling practical on-device learning. Applications across domains
such as computer vision, audio recognition, healthcare, and industrial
monitoring are reviewed to illustrate the real-world impact of TinyDL. Finally,
we identify emerging directions including neuromorphic computing, federated
TinyDL, edge-native foundation models, and domain-specific co-design
approaches. This survey aims to serve as a foundational resource for
researchers and practitioners, offering a holistic view of the ecosystem and
laying the groundwork for future advancements in edge AI.

AI.tldr: The paper surveys the transition from Tiny Machine Learning (TinyML) to Tiny Deep Learning (TinyDL) for deep learning on resource-constrained edge devices. It reviews methods, hardware trends, software frameworks, and applications.
AI.motivation: With the rise of edge devices, deploying AI on resource-constrained hardware has become crucial, prompting the evolution from TinyML (simple inference tasks) to TinyDL (deep learning for edge devices).
AI.method: The survey analyzes advanced techniques like quantization, pruning, NAS, hardware trends, software frameworks, and applications for TinyDL on edge devices.
AI.result: The paper categorizes cutting-edge tools, methods, and applications in TinyDL, while identifying emerging directions such as neuromorphic computing and federated approaches.
AI.conclusion: TinyDL represents a significant shift in edge AI, enabling advanced applications across various fields while addressing hardware and software constraints. The survey lays the foundation for future progress in the domain.

title: Faster Motion Planning via Restarts
comment: arXiv admin note: text overlap with arXiv:2503.04633
summary:
Randomized methods such as PRM and RRT are widely used in motion planning.
However, in some cases, their running-time suffers from inherent instability,
leading to ``catastrophic'' performance even for relatively simple instances.
We apply stochastic restart techniques, some of them new, for speeding up Las
Vegas algorithms, that provide dramatic speedups in practice (a factor of $3$
[or larger] in many cases).
  Our experiments demonstrate that the new algorithms have faster runtimes,
shorter paths, and greater gains from multi-threading (when compared with
straightforward parallel implementation). We prove the optimality of the new
variants. Our implementation is open source, available on github, and is easy
to deploy and use.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces stochastic restart techniques to improve motion planning algorithms, showing significant speedups and optimization.
AI.motivation: Randomized motion planning methods like PRM and RRT suffer from performance instability in certain cases.
AI.method: Stochastic restart techniques and new algorithm variants were applied to enhance the performance of Las Vegas algorithms.
AI.result: Experiments showed faster runtimes, shorter paths, and efficiency gains in multi-threading, outperforming parallel implementations.
AI.conclusion: The proposed methods are optimal, practical, and open source, with demonstrated benefits in motion planning tasks.

title: Dataset of Yul Contracts to Support Solidity Compiler Research
summary:
The YulCode dataset presents a comprehensive collection of 348,840 Yul-based
smart contract instances, comprising approximately 135,013 unique contracts.
These contracts were generated through the compilation of Solidity source files
that have been deployed on the Ethereum mainnet, making the dataset directly
representative of real-world decentralized applications. YulCode provides a
rich foundation for a variety of research and development tasks, including but
not limited to machine learning applications, formal verification, optimization
analysis, and software engineering tool evaluation in the context of low-level
smart contract code. To the best of our knowledge at the time of writing,
YulCode is the first and only publicly available dataset that focuses
specifically on Yul, an intermediate language designed for the Ethereum Virtual
Machine (EVM). As such, it fills a critical gap in the current ecosystem of
smart contract datasets and opens new avenues for research and tooling aimed at
low-level contract analysis and generation.

AI.tldr: YulCode is a dataset with 348,840 Yul-based smart contracts (135,013 unique), compiled from Ethereum Solidity sources to assist research and tooling in Yul, EVM's intermediate language.
AI.motivation: There is a lack of publicly available datasets focused on Yul, an intermediate language for Ethereum Virtual Machine, which hinders research and tooling development in this area.
AI.method: Collected 348,840 real-world Yul smart contracts by compiling Solidity source files from the Ethereum mainnet and curated the dataset.
AI.result: Created YulCode, the first publicly available dataset focusing solely on Yul contracts, fostering research in machine learning, optimization, verification, and software engineering for EVM.
AI.conclusion: YulCode fills a critical gap and provides a resource to advance low-level contract analysis, tooling, and innovation in the Ethereum ecosystem.

title: When Diffusion Models Memorize: Inductive Biases in Probability Flow of Minimum-Norm Shallow Neural Nets
comment:
Accepted to the Forty-second International Conference on Machine
  Learning (ICML 2025)
summary:
While diffusion models generate high-quality images via probability flow, the
theoretical understanding of this process remains incomplete. A key question is
when probability flow converges to training samples or more general points on
the data manifold. We analyze this by studying the probability flow of shallow
ReLU neural network denoisers trained with minimal $\ell^2$ norm. For
intuition, we introduce a simpler score flow and show that for orthogonal
datasets, both flows follow similar trajectories, converging to a training
point or a sum of training points. However, early stopping by the diffusion
time scheduler allows probability flow to reach more general manifold points.
This reflects the tendency of diffusion models to both memorize training
samples and generate novel points that combine aspects of multiple samples,
motivating our study of such behavior in simplified settings. We extend these
results to obtuse simplex data and, through simulations in the orthogonal case,
confirm that probability flow converges to a training point, a sum of training
points, or a manifold point. Moreover, memorization decreases when the number
of training samples grows, as fewer samples accumulate near training points.

AI.tldr: This paper analyzes diffusion models' probability flow dynamics and its convergence properties, exploring simplified cases to understand when the process memorizes training samples or generates novel manifold points.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to address the lack of theoretical understanding of when diffusion models' probability flow converges to training data or points on the data manifold.
AI.method: The study evaluates a shallow ReLU neural network denoiser with minimal l2 norm and simplifies the probability flow dynamics using score flow for orthogonal datasets, extending results to other configurations like obtuse simplex data.
AI.result: The results show that diffusion probability flow converges to either a training point, a sum of training points, or a manifold point, with reduced memorization as training dataset size increases.
AI.conclusion: Diffusion models exhibit both memorization and generalization. Early stopping, larger datasets, and simplified model setups can help understand and mitigate memorization behavior in these models.

title: Which Consciousness Can Be Artificialized? Local Percept-Perceiver Phenomenon for the Existence of Machine Consciousness
comment:
Paper accepted for the 18th Annual AGI Conference, AGI-2025,
  Reykjavik, Iceland, August 10-13, 2025
summary:
This paper presents a novel paradigm of the local percept-perceiver
phenomenon to formalize certain observations in neuroscientific theories of
consciousness. Using this model, a set-theoretic formalism is developed for
artificial systems, and the existence of machine consciousness is proved by
invoking Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory. The article argues for the possibility of
a reductionist form of epistemic consciousness within machines.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a formalism for machine consciousness using set theory, inspired by theories of human consciousness.
AI.motivation: To explore the possibility of machine consciousness by drawing from neuroscientific theories and formalizing them.
AI.method: The authors develop a set-theoretic model based on the local percept-perceiver paradigm and use Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory to analyze it.
AI.result: The possibility of epistemic consciousness within machines is proved mathematically using the presented model.
AI.conclusion: The study establishes a reductionist and theoretical foundation for understanding consciousness in artificial systems.

title: Robotics Under Construction: Challenges on Job Sites
summary:
As labor shortages and productivity stagnation increasingly challenge the
construction industry, automation has become essential for sustainable
infrastructure development. This paper presents an autonomous payload
transportation system as an initial step toward fully unmanned construction
sites. Our system, based on the CD110R-3 crawler carrier, integrates autonomous
navigation, fleet management, and GNSS-based localization to facilitate
material transport in construction site environments. While the current system
does not yet incorporate dynamic environment adaptation algorithms, we have
begun fundamental investigations into external-sensor based perception and
mapping system. Preliminary results highlight the potential challenges,
including navigation in evolving terrain, environmental perception under
construction-specific conditions, and sensor placement optimization for
improving autonomy and efficiency. Looking forward, we envision a construction
ecosystem where collaborative autonomous agents dynamically adapt to site
conditions, optimizing workflow and reducing human intervention. This paper
provides foundational insights into the future of robotics-driven construction
automation and identifies critical areas for further technological development.

AI.tldr: This paper discusses an autonomous material transportation system using the CD110R-3 crawler for construction sites, as a step towards fully unmanned construction operations.
AI.motivation: To address labor shortages and productivity stagnation in the construction industry through automation, enhancing infrastructure development's sustainability.
AI.method: The system integrates autonomous navigation, fleet management, and GNSS-based localization for material transport. It has fundamental investigations into perception and mapping but lacks dynamic environment adaptation.
AI.result: Preliminary results identify challenges like navigating changing terrain, environmental perception in construction conditions, and optimizing sensor placement.
AI.conclusion: The paper highlights a vision for collaborative autonomous agents dynamically adapting to site conditions, optimizing workflows, and reducing human involvement while providing foundational insights into robotics in construction automation.

title: Shelby: Decentralized Storage Designed to Serve
summary:
Existing decentralized storage protocols fall short of the service required
by real-world applications. Their throughput, latency, cost-effectiveness, and
availability are insufficient for demanding workloads such as video streaming,
large-scale data analytics, or AI training. As a result, Web3 data-intensive
applications are predominantly dependent on centralized infrastructure.
  Shelby is a high-performance decentralized storage protocol designed to meet
demanding needs. It achieves fast, reliable access to large volumes of data
while preserving decentralization guarantees. The architecture reflects lessons
from Web2 systems: it separates control and data planes, uses erasure coding
with low replication overhead and minimal repair bandwidth, and operates over a
dedicated backbone connecting RPC and storage nodes. Reads are paid, which
incentivizes good performance. Shelby also introduces a novel auditing protocol
that provides strong cryptoeconomic guarantees without compromising
performance, a common limitation of other decentralized solutions. The result
is a decentralized system that brings Web2-grade performance to
production-scale, read-intensive Web3 applications.

AI.tldr: Shelby is a decentralized storage protocol designed to handle intensive Web3 applications by delivering Web2-grade performance. It addresses shortcomings in throughput, latency, cost, and availability.
AI.motivation: Existing decentralized storage protocols are inadequate for high-demand applications such as video streaming and AI training, forcing Web3 to rely on centralized solutions.
AI.method: Shelby employs a Web2-inspired architecture: separation of control and data planes, erasure coding, a dedicated backbone connecting nodes, paid reads, and a new auditing protocol with strong cryptoeconomic guarantees.
AI.result: Shelby achieves reliable and fast access to large-scale data while maintaining decentralization, enabling its use for production-scale Web3 applications.
AI.conclusion: The Shelby protocol successfully bridges the gap between the performance needs of Web3 applications and decentralized storage paradigms, bringing decentralization and high efficiency together.

title: A Comment On "The Illusion of Thinking": Reframing the Reasoning Cliff as an Agentic Gap
comment:
10 pages, 2 figures, Comment on "The Illusion of Thinking:
  Understanding the Strengths and Limitations of Reasoning Models via the Lens
  of Problem Complexity" (arXiv:2506.06941v1)
summary:
The recent work by Shojaee et al. (2025), titled The Illusion of Thinking:
Understanding the Strengths and Limitations of Reasoning Models via the Lens of
Problem Complexity, presents a compelling empirical finding, a reasoning cliff,
where the performance of Large Reasoning Models (LRMs) collapses beyond a
specific complexity threshold, which the authors posit as an intrinsic scaling
limitation of Chain-of-Thought (CoT) reasoning. This commentary, while
acknowledging the study's methodological rigor, contends that this conclusion
is confounded by experimental artifacts. We argue that the observed failure is
not evidence of a fundamental cognitive boundary, but rather a predictable
outcome of system-level constraints in the static, text-only evaluation
paradigm, including tool use restrictions, context window recall issues, the
absence of crucial cognitive baselines, inadequate statistical reporting, and
output generation limits. We reframe this performance collapse through the lens
of an agentic gap, asserting that the models are not failing at reasoning, but
at execution within a profoundly restrictive interface. We empirically
substantiate this critique by demonstrating a striking reversal. A model,
initially declaring a puzzle impossible when confined to text-only generation,
now employs agentic tools to not only solve it but also master variations of
complexity far beyond the reasoning cliff it previously failed to surmount.
Additionally, our empirical analysis of tool-enabled models like o4-mini and
GPT-4o reveals a hierarchy of agentic reasoning, from simple procedural
execution to complex meta-cognitive self-correction, which has significant
implications for how we define and measure machine intelligence. The illusion
of thinking attributed to LRMs is less a reasoning deficit and more a
consequence of an otherwise capable mind lacking the tools for action.

AI.tldr: This paper critiques the concept of a reasoning cliff in LRMs, arguing it stems from system-level constraints rather than intrinsic reasoning limitations.
AI.motivation: The paper seeks to challenge the idea of a fundamental reasoning collapse in LRMs by exploring alternative explanations tied to experimental setup restrictions.
AI.method: The authors employed a tool-enhanced model approach to test reasoning capabilities beyond the text-only constraints and analyzed performance hierarchies.
AI.result: Tool-enabled models demonstrated the ability to overcome the reasoning cliff, showing advanced reasoning and problem-solving capabilities.
AI.conclusion: The observed reasoning collapse in LRMs is not a cognitive limitation but a result of restrictive evaluation methods, reaffirming the importance of tool integration.

title: Broken Tokens? Your Language Model can Secretly Handle Non-Canonical Tokenizations
summary:
Modern tokenizers employ deterministic algorithms to map text into a single
"canonical" token sequence, yet the same string can be encoded as many
non-canonical tokenizations using the tokenizer vocabulary. In this work, we
investigate the robustness of LMs to text encoded with non-canonical
tokenizations entirely unseen during training. Surprisingly, when evaluated
across 20 benchmarks, we find that instruction-tuned models retain up to 93.4%
of their original performance when given a randomly sampled tokenization, and
90.8% with character-level tokenization. We see that overall stronger models
tend to be more robust, and robustness diminishes as the tokenization departs
farther from the canonical form. Motivated by these results, we then identify
settings where non-canonical tokenization schemes can *improve* performance,
finding that character-level segmentation improves string manipulation and code
understanding tasks by up to +14%, and right-aligned digit grouping enhances
large-number arithmetic by +33%. Finally, we investigate the source of this
robustness, finding that it arises in the instruction-tuning phase. We show
that while both base and post-trained models grasp the semantics of
non-canonical tokenizations (perceiving them as containing misspellings), base
models try to mimic the imagined mistakes and degenerate into nonsensical
output, while post-trained models are committed to fluent responses. Overall,
our findings suggest that models are less tied to their tokenizer than
previously believed, and demonstrate the promise of intervening on tokenization
at inference time to boost performance.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates the robustness of language models (LMs) to non-canonical tokenizations and finds that instruction-tuned LMs perform robustly under such conditions, with specific tokenizations sometimes improving task performance.
AI.motivation: Standard tokenizers deterministically convert text into canonical token sequences, but real-world applications may involve non-canonical tokenizations. Investigating how LMs handle this variability can provide insights and potential performance improvements.
AI.method: The authors tested LMs such as instruction-tuned models across 20 benchmarks using various non-canonical tokenizations, including random sampling and character-level tokenizations, and analyzed robustness. They further examined character-level and digit-grouping tokenizations for specific tasks and traced robustness origins to the instruction-tuning phase.
AI.result: The study found that instruction-tuned models retained 93.4% performance with random tokenizations and 90.8% with character-level tokenizations. Furthermore, character-level tokenizations improved string manipulation and code tasks by 14%, while right-aligned digit grouping boosted arithmetic by 33%.
AI.conclusion: Language models, especially instruction-tuned ones, exhibit considerable robustness to unseen tokenizations, and performance can even improve in certain tasks through tokenization interventions, especially during inference.

title: Interpretable and Granular Video-Based Quantification of Motor Characteristics from the Finger Tapping Test in Parkinson Disease
summary:
Accurately quantifying motor characteristics in Parkinson disease (PD) is
crucial for monitoring disease progression and optimizing treatment strategies.
The finger-tapping test is a standard motor assessment. Clinicians visually
evaluate a patient's tapping performance and assign an overall severity score
based on tapping amplitude, speed, and irregularity. However, this subjective
evaluation is prone to inter- and intra-rater variability, and does not offer
insights into individual motor characteristics captured during this test. This
paper introduces a granular computer vision-based method for quantifying PD
motor characteristics from video recordings. Four sets of clinically relevant
features are proposed to characterize hypokinesia, bradykinesia, sequence
effect, and hesitation-halts. We evaluate our approach on video recordings and
clinical evaluations of 74 PD patients from the Personalized Parkinson Project.
Principal component analysis with varimax rotation shows that the video-based
features corresponded to the four deficits. Additionally, video-based analysis
has allowed us to identify further granular distinctions within sequence effect
and hesitation-halts deficits. In the following, we have used these features to
train machine learning classifiers to estimate the Movement Disorder Society
Unified Parkinson Disease Rating Scale (MDS-UPDRS) finger-tapping score.
Compared to state-of-the-art approaches, our method achieves a higher accuracy
in MDS-UPDRS score prediction, while still providing an interpretable
quantification of individual finger-tapping motor characteristics. In summary,
the proposed framework provides a practical solution for the objective
assessment of PD motor characteristics, that can potentially be applied in both
clinical and remote settings. Future work is needed to assess its
responsiveness to symptomatic treatment and disease progression.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a computer vision-based approach for objectively quantifying motor deficits in Parkinson's disease using finger-tapping tests from video recordings, offering improved accuracy and granular assessment over traditional subjective methods.
AI.motivation: Current assessment of motor deficits in Parkinson's disease using finger-tapping tests relies on subjective clinician evaluation, which is prone to variability and does not provide detailed insights into specific motor characteristics.
AI.method: The researchers developed a computer vision-based framework to analyze video recordings of finger-tapping in Parkinson's patients. They extracted features related to hypokinesia, bradykinesia, sequence effect, and hesitation-halts, and utilized principal component analysis to validate these features. Machine learning models were then trained to predict MDS-UPDRS finger-tapping scores.
AI.result: The proposed method demonstrated higher prediction accuracy for finger-tapping scores compared to existing approaches, while also enabling granular identification of specific motor deficits from video data.
AI.conclusion: This framework offers an objective, interpretable, and accurate method for assessing Parkinson's disease motor characteristics. It holds promise for use in both clinical and remote settings, with further research required for evaluating its effectiveness in tracking treatment outcomes and disease progression.

title: Safe Pruning LoRA: Robust Distance-Guided Pruning for Safety Alignment in Adaptation of LLMs
summary:
Fine-tuning Large Language Models (LLMs) with Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA)
enhances adaptability while reducing computational costs. However, fine-tuning
can compromise safety alignment, even with benign data, increasing
susceptibility to harmful outputs. Existing safety alignment methods struggle
to capture complex parameter shifts, leading to suboptimal safety-utility
trade-offs. To address this issue, we propose Safe Pruning LoRA (SPLoRA), a
novel pruning-based approach that selectively removes LoRA layers that weaken
safety alignment, improving safety while preserving performance. At its core,
we introduce Empirical-DIEM (E-DIEM), a dimension-insensitive similarity metric
that effectively detects safety misalignment in LoRA-adapted models. We conduct
extensive experiments on LLMs fine-tuned with mixed of benign and malicious
data, and purely benign datasets, evaluating SPLoRA across utility, safety, and
reliability metrics. Results demonstrate that SPLoRA outperforms
